Attribute
list.item: In XML, a property of an element. Properties are given in the opening tag of an element.
list.label: Cache
list.item: A local or optimised copy of a remote document that avoids repeated processing and thus enhances performance.
list.label: CSS
list.item: Cascading Stylesheets: define styles for HTML pages (borders, margins, font size, etc.). Not to be confused with XSLT stylesheets.
list.label: Element
list.item: In text encoding based on XML, a fragment of text delimited by opening and closing tags. The text is described by a hierarchical structure of elements. Elements may contain oher elements and/or text, but can also be empty. Properties of elements can be given in attributes.
list.label: HTML
list.item: HyperText Markup Language, the language used to write web pages.
list.label: namespace
list.item: Namespaces are collections of XML elements that belong to some common vocabulary. All TEI elements belong to the TEI namespace. XML documents can use elements from multiple namespaces. See
list.label: OCR
list.item: Optical Character Recognition: Process whereby a computer program interprets a scanned page and outputs (something more or less like) the text written on that page.
list.label: ODD
list.item: One Document Does it all: document describing a TEI schema. See

URL
list.item: Uniform Resource Locator. An internet address, such as . A URL need not be absolute (contain a full address) but can also be relative to the current address, such as 'images/page4.jpg'. A URL can point to a location in the current document by using the value of an xml:id attribute somewhere in the document, preceded by '#'.
list.label: wysiwyg
list.item: What You See Is What You Get. In modern word processors, what you see is what you get: the document on the screen looks like the document that comes out of the printer. Word processors can work this way because the information in the document serves a single purpose: it is meant to look a certain way and that is it. The information in an XML document is meant to be used in multiple ways, and therefore there is no single 'what you get'. See
list.label: XML
list.item: eXtensible Mark-up Language. For the purposes of the TEI, XML can be seen as a generic syntax for encoding properties, structural and others, of texts. The TEI encoding scheme is applied using XML. But non-textual data structures can also be expressed using XML. See .
list.label: XML Processing Instruction
XML schema
list.item: A schema describes the elements and attributes (and their combinations) that can occur in an XML document. A schema is necessary for XML validation. The TEI uses three schema languages DTD, XSD (also known as W3C Schema) and Relax NG. This document uses Relax NG.
list.label: XSD / W3C Schema
XSLT
list.item: eXtensible Stylesheet Language - Transformations. Language that is used to define transformations from XML documents into new XML documents, HTML documents, or plain text documents.
